passages.text: - Real GDP contracted \(1.6\%\) ar in 2Q25 as the trade war pummeled exports- Net trade and equipment investment were the largest detractors from 2Q growth; household spending rebounded strongly last quarter- Monthly GDP returned to growth in July's flash estimate, but preliminary estimates are prone to significant revisions

Real GDP growth for 2Q25 contracted \(1.6\%\) q/q saar, a sharper decline than both our forecast and the consensus expectation for a more modest downturn. 1Q25 growth was revised down to \(2.0\%\) ar from the previously reported \(2.2\%\) . This weaker- than- expected print marks the end of the above- trend growth trajectory observed over the past five quarters, as the boost from front- loading behavior ahead of tariffs, which had kept overall activity robust at the start of the year, sharply reversed in 2Q. While a strong rebound in household consumption suggests the trade war's impact hadn't fully permeated the broader economy last quarter, more timely labor market data are hinting at weakness spreading beyond sectors directly exposed to the trade conflict. With no indication of tariff relief forthcoming, growth is likely to remain weak this quarter.

The details of the report show a sharp pullback in the largest contributors to strong 1Q growth, indicating that weakness last quarter was exacerbated by the reversal of earlier front- loading behavior. A \(26.8\%\) ar plunge in exports was the largest drag on 2Q GDP, subtracting \(9.8\%\) - pt from overall growth. Net trade was an \(8.1\%\) - pt drag on growth, as imports also fell \(5.1\%\) ar last quarter. Business equipment investment contracted \(32.6\%\) ar, marking its weakest reading in the post- pandemic period, and leaving overall private fixed capital investment down \(2.4\%\) ar. These components of growth are likely to remain weak while tariff uncertainty remains high. Meanwhile, real household spending rebounded to \(4.5\%\) ar last quarter, a sharp pickup from the \(0.5\%\) pace in the 1Q. This increase reflected stronger growth in real spending on both goods \((+4.7\%)\) and services \((+4.3\%)\) . Government spending also rebounded to \(5.7\%\) ar in 2Q after a rare contraction in the prior quarter. Inventions provided a boost of \(3.1\%\) - pt.

Monthly GDP for June fell by \(0.1\%\) , as a \(- 0.5\%\) contraction in goods- producing industries offset \(0.1\%\) growth in services activity. Weaker manufacturing output \((- 1.5\%)\) and utilities \((- 1.2\%)\) led the decline on the goods side. The sharpest downturn was seen in transportation equipment manufacturing \((- 4.4\%)\) . Retail trade, meanwhile, fully rebounded from a May contraction with a \(1.4\%\) rise in June, while real estate and rental and leasing \((+0.3\%)\) and wholesale trade \((+0.5\%)\) continued to expand. Although Statistics Canada's flash estimate for a return to \(0.1\%\) growth in July puts output- based real GDP on track for very soft yet positive 3Q, these preliminary estimates are prone to significant revisions. StatCan's flash estimate for June similarly predicted a return to growth, yet today's report revealed a third consecutive month of declining activity at the close of 2Q.
Overall, today's print confirmed our prior view that a significant trade war shock pushed the Canadian economy into contraction last quarter. Stronger underlying
See page 5 for analyst certification and important disclosures.
Economic and Policy Research

household consumption in 2Q suggests that the broader economy has not yet fully felt the brunt of the trade war, and we believe that some of this apparent strength is attributable to the tail-end of front-loaded spending ahead of anticipated tariff-related price hikes. The Bank of Canada's Survey on Business Conditions for 3Q released earlier this week suggests that a large share of firms have been delaying passing on tariff costs to consumers. While confirmation of weak 2Q growth alone is unlikely to sway the Bank of Canada in favor of resuming rate cuts at its meeting next month, the Bank has signaled that it would consider cutting rates if the economy continues to show signs of weakness and upward price pressures from trade disruptions remain contained. In our view, a weak August Labour Force Survey and stable core CPI in August could be sufficient to tilt the balance in favor of a rate cut on September 17.
Canada: Real GDP %q/q, saar
Source: Statistics Canada, J.P. Morgan
Source: Statistics Canada, J.P. Morgan
Source: Statistics Canada, J.P. Morgan
\%- pt contribution to real GDP growth, saar
Quarterly real GDP growth %q/q saar, except as noted
Source: Statistics Canada, J.P. Morgan
